content.webTitle: England 0-1 USA | Women’s friendly international match report

fields.headline: England fall short against USA as Alex Morgan header proves decisive
fields.bodyText: England deserved at least a draw, insisted their head coach Mark Sampson after a game in which his team had an equalising goal incorrectly ruled out for offside after the striker Alex Morgan’s 25th-minute opener for the USA. But after another defeat to one of the world’s top nations, and with the World Cup finals in Canada only four months away, Sampson concluded ruefully that, “eventually, we’ve got to find away to win.” Finding a way to win against the best will be vital if England are to be successful in the summer, but despite a defeat against the world’s second best side coming in the wake of November’s 3-0 trouncing by Germany, the top team, at Wembley, Sampson feels his side are on track. “I’m very pleased with the progress the team have made,” he said, “and we’re keen to take on more of these challenges. The work ethic of the players tonight was outstanding, and we deserved at least a draw – especially bearing in mind we scored a perfectly good goal. “We weren’t cut open at all and although the Americans got too many balls into the box for our liking, we defended those crosses admirably in the main.” Sampson had made five changes from the team that lost to Germany, dropping his midfield diamond formation for a more solid 4-4-2. “It worked well,” he said, “the two centre backs and two central midfielders stepped up to the plate and we stood up well to America’s physicality. “It’s about learning and the team getting better. The players had dusted themselves down after the Germany game and they were much better tonight.” One player unable to “step up to the plate” was the Chelsea captain Katie Chapman, recalled to the squad after four years in the international wilderness but an unused substitute. Chapman had been in an unwanted “retirement” after childcare issues, leading to an impasse with the former coach Hope Powell that had resulted in her departure. “It would have been great to get Katie some minutes,” said Sampson. “I’m sure she would have loved that opportunity. It was a real special moment in the team room earlier today when Katie got handed her jersey, I think she certainly shed a few tears, it was an important moment for her but the most important thing for Katie was to get her back in the group and see how she fitted in – and she fitted in fantastically well. “It would have been nice to get her on if the circumstances had been different, but unfortunately they weren’t. We would have liked to be ahead and get Katie on to see it out, but I’m sure she’ll play a big part for us in the future.” After a tentative opening, the decisive goal came when the USA midfielder Lauren Holiday crossed for Morgan to head home all too easily after 25 minutes. It was the 50th goal of her career in 79 appearances. England struggled to create too many clear-cut chances but their best came when the Reading striker Fran Kirby lofted in a 20-yard shot that was turned on to the crossbar by the keeper Ashlyn Harris, and though Kirby’s strike partner Jodie Taylor tucked in the rebound the flag was up for offside – though replays showed that she had been well onside.
